questions.text: During the assessment of the health planning activities of a village, it was found that investing 2% more in the procurement of anti-hypertensive drugs reduced the incidence of Cerebrovascular accidents by 10% compared to the previous year. Which of the following Management method has been used in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cost-effective analysis In cost-effective analysis, the program's benefits are analyzed in terms of results achieved rather than expressed in monetary terms. In cost-benefit analysis, the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of that program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to determine whether a given program is economically sound and to select the best out of several alternate programs. Cost accounting provides data on the cost structure of any program. Financial records are kept in a manner permitting costs to be associated with the purpose for which they are incurred. Network analysis is a graphical plan of all events and activities to be completed to reach an end objective.

questions.text: While assessing the drug stocks register at a PHC, it was found that 10% of drugs cost around 70% of the total expenditure, 20% of drugs cost 20% & 70% cost around 10%. Which of the following inventory control technique has been used for this assessment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Always, Better, Control analysis Always Better Control or ABC analysis is a type of Inventory technique based on the principles of Pareto’s law, i.e., Vital few and trivial many. 70%, 20%, and 10% of the total items would cost 10%, 20%, and 70%, respectively. Vital, Essential, and Desirable analysis or VED analysis is a type of inventory control technique based on criticality and importance rather than just on the cost of consumption. Drugs are classified into three categories- Life-saving vital medicines, which should never be stockout; essential drugs, whose one-two days stockout can be tolerable & Desirable; the stockout can be fair for longer. FIFO or First In First Out is a concept in inventory control wherein items received earlier should be first out to use. In the pull system of inventory control, materials are always obtained based on the demand from the lower side where materials are used.
